Summary Highly passionate about exploiting technology to support the requirements of people and the enterprises. I am interested to build applications required for large scale data acquisition, information processing, knowledge discovery and effective decision making.  
 
Professional with Masters degree in Computer Science and extensive industry experience in Business Intelligence Data and Reporting projects (Microstrategy and ETL Development). Certified Microstrategy Project Designer. Certified ETL Developer. Proficient with Big Data technologies (Hadoop, Map Reduce, HIVE, Pig, Sqoop), analytical model building (Python, SAS, R, JMP), data mining, programming and data warehousing technologies (Teradata, Oracle).  
 
Specialities 
 
Business Intelligence Tools: Microstrategy, Tableau 
Big Data Technologies: Hadoop, Sqoop, Flume, Hive, Pig, Pig-Latin, Storm 
Database and Data Warehouse: Oracle, Teradata, SQL Server, NoSQL Databases (i.e. Mongo DB) 
Programming: Java, Python, SQL, NoSQL, PL/SQL, C, C++, MATLAB  
Statistical & Data Mining Software: SAS, R, JMP, WEKA, LightSIDE  
Web Development: PHP, HTML, CSS, JavaScript  
 
 
Volunteer Experience: 
 
As part of Intel Involved in Bangalore India, We worked closely with Sparsha Trust to rehabilitate and educate more than 800 children in 2 years. Experience BI Tech Lead Travelers August 2015  – Present (1 month) Hartford, Connecticut Area Assistant in Analytics Texas A&M University January 2015  –  May 2015  (5 months) Bryan/College Station, Texas Area Position: Student Worker/ Assistant in Analytics, Department of Statistics 
 
Performed in-depth data mining, analysis, and modeling under the guidance of Dr. Simon Sheather, Distinguished Professor and Academic Director of MS in the Analytics program. 
 
(1) Targeted data mining from social media, through the Facebook API and the Twitter API using  
Python, to glean social promotion activities by top museums in New York City.  
(2) Designed a Poisson Log-Linear Regression model, accurately forecasting exhibition attendance from social media sentiments. 
 
 User Experience Researcher Intel Corporation September 2012  –  July 2013  (11 months) Bangalore Project: Ultrabook UX Research 
 
(1) Demonstrated great vision and critical thinking by suggesting usability improvements in the development of Intel’s 2nd generation Ultrabooks.  
(2) Involved in User Centered Research and Evaluation (UCRE), Contextual inquiry, heuristic evaluation, inteviewing participants and synthesizing information for Visioning. 
 Project Lead Intel February 2011  –  July 2013  (2 years 6 months) Bangalore Project: Perfect Order Metrics 
Program: Customer Excellence Program 
 
(1) Drove corporate achievement of best-in-class Perfect Order Score with metrics, developed on Teradata and Microstrategy, effectively boosting Intel Corporation’s AMR Research rank from 25th to 7th . 
(2) Involved in establishing the Key Performance Indicators, system analysis, data analysis, requirements formulation, converting requirements to functional/technical design documents, Microstrategy Development, configuring distribution services, ETL Development, writing stored procedures, query optimization, usability evaluation, functional testing and mentoring the developers. 
 Application Developer Lead Intel July 2006  –  January 2011  (4 years 7 months) Bangalore Project: My Supply Chain BI Portal 
 
(1) Analyzed the My Supply Chain BI application stack on Microsoft ASP and SQL Server 2005 technology. Designed and built the migrated BI reporting capabilities on BI tools Microstrategy and Teradata. The project saved several million USD for Intel Corporation.  
(2) The Self-Service BI, What-If-Analysis and Writeback features implemented in the project were well-appreciated by the customers and the team was awarded with the Division Recognition Award. 
(3) Involved in creation of Microstrategy Schema objects and public objects, development of interactive Dashboards, freeform SQL reports, In-Memory cube (IMA) reports and writeback reports. (4) Performed data flow analysis, ETL development and performance tuning.

Summary My personal mission is to create products and experiences that make "sense". It is my goal to integrate ergonomic concepts with innovative design principles. I would like to create human-centered designs that integrate technology and culture, while being comfortable, salient, and asthetically appealing. 
 
Currently, I am conducting research in The Human-Centered Computing Lab at Clemson University where I am evaluating user experiences across multiple mediums, in an attempt to get insights on how to make more informed design decisions. Experience Graduate Research Assistant Human Experience Research Lab at The University of Florida August 2014  – Present (1 year 1 month) User Experience Designer, User Experience Researcher Intel Corporation June 2014  –  August 2014  (3 months) Hillsboro, OR Our team created multiple proofs of concept to create immersive user experiences for the news and magazine segment, innovating the way users can consume content. By integrating Intel RealSense Technology and the Perceptual Computing SDK, we enabled 360° panoramic video with touch and gesture interactions. We also innovated ways to curate and annotate this content into a working prototype. We demonstrated our work at the headquarters of a prominent news and media company, securing a commit win for this solution. I used tools such as Balsamiq to create wireframes and sketches that illustrated compelling usages of our technology. I also provided an implementation guide for partner’s existing websites. 
 
During this internship, I was also able to work with a UX Firm (Empir- acle) to perform a Heuristic Evaluation of Mozzilla Firefox. We were tasked with making suggested improvements for ways to optimize the Firefox experience on Intel 2 in 1 devices. Graduate Research Assistant - Human-Centered Computing Lab Clemson University May 2011  –  May 2014  (3 years 1 month) User Experience Designer Intel Corporation May 2013  –  August 2013  (4 months) Santa Clara, CA For my second Intel internship I worked in the Interaction Experience Research group. I was tasked with understanding camera array technology and using that understanding to create meaningful experiences that would get consumers excited about the future of photography and camera arrays. I worked with a team of other engineers to building a working prototype using 9 Go-Pro cameras and a hardware rig. It was my responsibility to also create a presentation that would showcase the array technology, and possible use cases. As the UX designer I brainstormed use cases, scouted locations to capture camera array images for the presentation and created a concept video that would highlight an innovative experience. Lead PEER Mentor Clemson University August 2009  –  May 2013  (3 years 10 months) Clemson, SC Responsible for several minority freshman engineering students, hold weekly meetings to help with their assimilation into college life and assist them with homework while serving as an all around role model (academic and social mentoring). Also responsible for 10 other mentors. UX Intern in the Automotive Solutions Division Intel Corporation May 2012  –  August 2012  (4 months) As an UX intern, I created personas and day-in-the-life narratives which were instrumental in assessing the needs and wants of consumers and providing a foundation to streamline the efforts of various groups within the division. Assessed user experience through first and second hand value-added research, thereby strengthening the validity of market segmentation findings. Finally, developed innovative solutions and defined interactions through the design of use cases for potentially lucrative market segments, which served to supplement the implementation of new technology. Summary I'm currently a second year undergrad student at Oberlin College pursuing a dual degree in Psychology and Sociology with a minor in Africana studies. I love understanding what makes people tick, and as a college student, am incredibly aware of the rapidly intersecting spheres of social media and our day to day communication. Dating, finding a job, and making new friends now have completely new social rules with the creation of Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and other media outlets.  
 
I want to understand those rules, and perhaps even create them. I hope to develop technologies that will allow the user to explore their connections with others, and understand the ways in which our social relationships may be bettered through social media outlets. 
 
A way in which I navigate my world is through the eyes of a poet. I have been writing since I was able to string together the alphabet as a child.Poetry and creative expression are integral components of my life. When I am not pursuing research for my Psychology and Sociology professors, I am acting as a team leader for Oberlin College's slam poetry team and club. I help writers across campus express their thoughts, feelings, and emotions through the poetic medium, and in doing so, work to bring my campus together through the power and catharsis of poetry. Through my poetry, I hope to ignite social change in communities across the world. Currently, I am pursing a project that will support economically under privileged girls aged 8-16 in writing poetry, as a way to build not only self esteem but community, which will eventually lead to incredible self empowerment. Summary I've always had a natural curiosity about how people think, behave, and feel. By understanding people’s mental models and how they make sense of the world, it helps identify new opportunities to design something that people would actually find valuable and meaningful.  
 
Ultimately, the decision to choose one product/service over another can partly be attributed to its features. However, there is more to consumer decision making than simply comparing product/services at the feature level. Oftentimes, the most influential factors shaping what and why we buy are our perceptions, goals, and values. For that reason, throughout my career and academic studies I have studied people from a multidisciplinary approach of psychology, economic, user experience, and human factors engineering.
